articles.headline: $1.2 Billion Fine for Hedge Fund SAC Capital in Insider Case
articles.snippet: The hedge fund owned by Steven A. Cohen has agreed to pay a record $1.2 billion penalty, becoming the first large Wall Street firm in a generation to confess to criminal conduct.
articles.abstract: The hedge fund owned by Steven A. Cohen has agreed to pay a record $1.2 billion penalty, becoming the first large Wall Street firm in a generation to confess to criminal conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen sat at the center of his vast trading floor on Monday, buying and selling stocks. In a sign of his enduring influence on Wall Street, he did business with major banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: J.&J. to Pay $2.2 Billion in Risperdal Settlement
articles.snippet: Federal officials said Johnson & Johnson promoted the antipsychotic drug as a way to treat dementia patients for many ailments, when it was only approved for schizophrenia.
articles.abstract: Federal officials said Johnson & Johnson promoted the antipsychotic drug as a way to treat dementia patients for many ailments, when it was only approved for schizophrenia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay more than $2.2 billion in criminal and civil fines to settle accusations that it improperly promoted the antipsychotic drug Risperdal to older adults, children and people with developmental disabilities, the Justice Department said on Monday.

articles.headline: SAC: A Textbook Case of Corporate Prosecution
articles.snippet: The decision to indict a company is one way to punish wrongdoing and influence deterrence.
articles.abstract: The decision to indict a company is one way to punish wrongdoing and influence deterrence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAC Capital’s guilty plea to insider trading and $1.2 billion fine may represent a sweeping victory for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney, and his team of prosecutors, and vindication for their multiyear investigation of one of the country’s most successful hedge funds. But the decision to indict a company, and to spare, at least for now, its founder and billionaire manager, Steven A. Cohen, has already ignited criticism.

articles.headline: After a Decade, SAC Capital Blinks
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s deal with SAC Capital Advisors caps an investigation that turned a mighty hedge fund into a symbol of financial wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s deal with SAC Capital Advisors caps an investigation that turned a mighty hedge fund into a symbol of financial wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors first sought to fend off a federal indictment. Then the hedge fund, run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, offered to pay about $700 million to settle. Finally, SAC suggested it plead guilty to only some of the criminal charges in the five-count indictment.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: U.S. in Talks to Settle Suit Over American-US Airways Merger
articles.snippet: The negotiations raised hopes that the merger of the two airlines would proceed with relatively modest concessions.
articles.abstract: The negotiations raised hopes that the merger of the two airlines would proceed with relatively modest concessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has started talks with American Airlines and US Airways, seeking concessions on airport takeoff and landing slots in exchange for dropping an antitrust lawsuit aimed at blocking their merger, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Monday
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: For Uninsured, Clearing a Way to Enrollment
articles.snippet: Kentucky and other states are using counselors to seek out and sign up uninsured residents, providing a clear view of how enrollment under the health care law should work.
articles.abstract: Kentucky and other states are using counselors to seek out and sign up uninsured residents, providing a clear view of how enrollment under the health care law should work.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA GRANGE, Ky. — Kelli Cauley’s fingers raced over her keyboard as she asked the anxious woman at her side a series of questions. What was her income? How many people lived in her household? Did she smoke? (“That’s the only health question it asks,” Ms. Cauley said of the application they were completing.)

articles.headline: After Outside Pressure, Rebels in Congo Lay Down Their Arms
articles.snippet: The surrender offered new hope for a region where conflict has gone on for so many years that it has often come to seem almost inevitable.
articles.abstract: The surrender offered new hope for a region where conflict has gone on for so many years that it has often come to seem almost inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Col. Mamadou Moustafa stood at the front lines of the battle for eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, surveying his soldiers fighting to dislodge rebels from the surrounding hills.

articles.headline: Ford Pays a High Price for Plant Closing in Belgium
articles.snippet: Ford’s plant in Genk, Belgium, is scheduled to close at the end of the year, but only after a long, bitter struggle that cost the company $750 million.
articles.abstract: Ford’s plant in Genk, Belgium, is scheduled to close at the end of the year, but only after a long, bitter struggle that cost the company $750 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENK, Belgium — Rumors of job cuts at the big Ford plant in this scruffy former coal mining town had been circulating for months. But on a clear morning a year ago, almost nobody in Genk expected what came next.
